solution_line_template: Noah’s bedroom light uses {bedroom_wph} watts per hour, so it would use {hours_on} * {bedroom_wph} = <<{bedroom_wph}*{hours_on}={bedroom_total}>>{bedroom_total} watts in two hours.

His office light uses {office_multiplier} times as many watts as his bedroom light, so it uses {office_multiplier} * {bedroom_wph} = <<{office_multiplier}*{bedroom_wph}={office_wph}>>{office_wph} watts per hour.
In two hours, the office light would use {office_wph} * {hours_on} = <<{office_wph}*{hours_on}={office_total}>>{office_total} watts.

The living room light uses {living_multiplier} times as many watts as his bedroom light, so it uses {living_multiplier} * {bedroom_wph} = <<{living_multiplier}*{bedroom_wph}={living_wph}>>{living_wph} watts per hour.
In two hours, the living room light would use {living_wph} * {hours_on} = <<{living_wph}*{hours_on}={living_total}>>{living_total} watts.

Thus, if Noah leaves all those lights on for two hours, he has used {bedroom_total} + {office_total} + {living_total} = <<{bedroom_total}+{office_total}+{living_total}={total_watts}>>{total_watts} watts.
